page.title: 04THE CHURCH - BUILDINGS
page.content: West Pennard parish church is typical of many Somerset churches, being medieval and having a tower. The church is of the late medieval period but it was not all built at the same time.The arches on the north side of the aisle are uniform and those on the south are irregular.The church was originally part of the manor of West Pennard and owned by the Abbot of Glastonbury. In the early 19th century it became an independent benefice but has just returned to the guardianship of St.John Baptist (Glastonbury) as part of the Abbey Five with one vicar covering five parishes. The tower holds 6 bells dating from 1604 to 1879. The south wall of the tower has a smooth facing which was added in the 19th century for playing fives. The west wall has a clock that must be wound once a week.
